models.name: First Principles Framing
models.definition: Reduce complex problems to foundational truths that cannot be further simplified
models.example: When redesigning pricing strategy, start with unit costs and desired margin rather than competitor benchmarks.

models.name: Stakeholder Mapping
models.definition: Identify all parties with interest, influence, or impact in a system or decision
models.example: Before launching a gait analysis service, map clinicians, patients, payers, and facility administrators with their respective goals.

models.name: Identity Stack
models.definition: Recognize that individuals operate from multiple nested identities simultaneously
models.example: A team lead switches between personal values, role responsibilities, team culture, and company mission when making decisions.

models.name: Lens Shifting
models.definition: Deliberately adopt different interpretive frameworks to reveal hidden aspects of a situation
models.example: Analyze declining engagement through operational efficiency, user motivation, and data quality lenses sequentially.

models.name: Empathy Mapping
models.definition: Systematically capture what stakeholders see, think, feel, and do in their context
models.example: Draft onboarding materials after mapping what new members observe, worry about, experience emotionally, and attempt initially.

models.name: Point-of-View Anchoring
models.definition: Establish and maintain a consistent reference frame before analysis begins
models.example: Evaluate all feature requests from the anchor of member lifetime value rather than switching between cost, effort, and novelty.

models.name: Perspective Switching
models.definition: Rotate through multiple viewpoints to identify invariants and blind spots
models.example: Review policy changes from staff operations, member experience, legal compliance, and financial impact perspectives before finalizing.

models.name: Narrative Framing
models.definition: Structure information as causal stories with conflict, choice, and consequence
models.example: Present roadmap as member journey obstacles, strategic decisions made, and expected outcomes rather than feature lists.

models.name: Cultural Lens Shifting
models.definition: Adjust communication and interpretation for different cultural contexts and norms
models.example: Adapt health messaging between medical professional, fitness enthusiast, and general wellness audiences with appropriate metaphors and emphasis.

models.name: Context Windowing
models.definition: Define explicit boundaries in time, space, and scope for analysis or action
models.example: Limit quarterly revenue review to eastern region only, excluding ongoing pilots and international operations.

models.name: Role Perspective-Taking
models.definition: Temporarily inhabit specific roles to understand constraints and priorities
models.example: When designing admin tools, spend sessions thinking as customer service rep, billing specialist, and compliance officer.

models.name: Temporal Framing
models.definition: Organize understanding across past causes, present states, and future implications
models.example: Structure strategic review around historical decisions that led here, current positioning, and trajectory toward goals.

models.name: Spatial Framing
models.definition: Scale perspective from local details to global patterns and back
models.example: Analyze checkout abandonment at individual click level, page flow, entire funnel, and cross-site industry patterns.

models.name: Reference Class Framing
models.definition: Select comparable situations to inform judgment and avoid uniqueness bias
models.example: Forecast new market entry by studying three similar companies in adjacent markets rather than assuming unprecedented circumstances.

models.name: Assumption Surfacing
models.definition: Explicitly identify and document beliefs underlying plans or models
models.example: Before launching subscription tier, list assumptions about conversion rates, retention, support costs, and competitive response.

models.name: Identity-Context Reciprocity
models.definition: Recognize how identities shape interpretations and contexts reinforce identities
models.example: Acknowledge that company culture influences how leaders frame problems, which then reinforces that same culture.

models.name: Frame Control & Reframing
models.definition: Consciously select or reshape interpretive frames to enable new solutions
models.example: Transform budget deficit into investment prioritization opportunity to shift team from cuts to strategic allocation.

models.name: Boundary Object Selection
models.definition: Choose representations that bridge multiple perspectives while remaining meaningful to each
models.example: Use customer journey maps as boundary objects between design, engineering, marketing, and support teams.

models.name: Sensemaking Canvases
models.definition: Deploy structured templates to systematically capture and organize observations
models.example: Use business model canvas to map value proposition, customer segments, channels, and cost structure during market analysis.

models.name: Worldview Articulation
models.definition: Make explicit the fundamental beliefs and values that drive interpretation and action
models.example: Document team's shared worldview about user agency, data ethics, and platform responsibility before designing recommendation systems.

models.name: Subtractive Thinking
models.definition: Improve systems by removing elements rather than adding complexity
models.example: Strip features from product until value proposition breaks, then restore only the last removed feature.

models.name: Premortem Analysis
models.definition: Assume failure has occurred and work backward to identify causes
models.example: Six months before launch, gather team to explain why the product failed spectacularly, capturing risks that optimism obscures.

models.name: Problem Reversal
models.definition: Solve the inverse of the stated problem to reveal insights
models.example: Ask how would we guarantee maximum customer churn to identify anti-retention patterns currently present.

models.name: Contra-Logic
models.definition: Argue the opposite position to stress-test assumptions and expose weak reasoning
models.example: Defend users prefer offline interaction thoroughly to validate digital-first strategy against strongest counterargument.

models.name: Negative Space Framing
models.definition: Study what is absent rather than what is present
models.example: Identify which customer segments never convert and investigate why, rather than only analyzing successful conversions.

models.name: Inverse/Proof by Contradiction
models.definition: Assume a claim is false, derive logical impossibility, thus proving the claim true
models.example: Test capacity model by assuming queue never grows and demonstrating mathematical contradiction under realistic load.

models.name: Boundary Testing
models.definition: Explore extreme conditions to find system limits and breaking points
models.example: Test pricing sensitivity at $0 and 10× current price to understand elasticity range and psychological anchors.

models.name: Contrapositive Reasoning
models.definition: Use logical equivalence that if A then B equals if not B then not A
models.example: If no referral spike follows campaign, then campaign was not viral, revealing misclassification of effort.

models.name: Backward Induction
models.definition: Begin with desired end state and work backward to determine necessary steps
models.example: Start from passing certification audit and work backward through documentation, controls, and process changes needed.

models.name: Red Teaming
models.definition: Organize adversarial review to find vulnerabilities through simulated attack
models.example: Conduct security tabletop where designated team attempts to break authentication flow using realistic attack vectors.

models.name: Devil's Advocate Protocol
models.definition: Assign explicit role to argue against group consensus or preferred option
models.example: Designate team member to comprehensively challenge acquisition strategy, forcing examination of unspoken assumptions.

models.name: Failure First Design
models.definition: Begin planning by identifying all possible failure modes and designing to prevent them
models.example: Architect data pipeline by first listing every way it could lose, corrupt, or duplicate data, then adding safeguards.

models.name: Opportunity Cost Focus
models.definition: Evaluate options by what must be forgone rather than what is gained
models.example: Frame hiring decision as we can't pursue mobile app if we staff this platform expansion to clarify tradeoffs.

models.name: Second-Order Effects (Inverted)
models.definition: Trace negative downstream consequences rather than immediate benefits
models.example: Before adding gamification, consider how it might reduce intrinsic motivation, create perverse incentives, or exclude accessibility needs.

models.name: Constraint Reversal
models.definition: Temporarily remove assumed constraints to explore alternative solution space
models.example: Design workshop where team plans with unlimited budget to identify features cut only due to resource limits, not strategic fit.

models.name: Inverse Optimization
models.definition: Maximize worst outcomes to understand system vulnerabilities
models.example: Optimize schedule to maximize context switching and interruptions to identify how current practices harm productivity.

models.name: Counterfactual Negation
models.definition: Imagine outcomes if key decision had been reversed
models.example: Evaluate what if we had not acquired that company to assess merger's actual contribution versus assumed value.

models.name: Kill-Criteria & Stop Rules
models.definition: Define conditions that trigger project termination before launch
models.example: Establish if beta retention falls below 40% after two iterations, we kill this feature to prevent sunk cost fallacy.

models.name: Harm Minimization (Via Negativa)
models.definition: Improve by removing harmful elements rather than adding beneficial ones
models.example: Audit codebase to identify and delete unused dependencies, reducing attack surface and maintenance burden.

models.name: Antigoals & Anti-Patterns Catalog
models.definition: Document failure modes to avoid rather than success patterns to emulate
models.example: Maintain team wiki of ways we've broken production with root causes to prevent recurrence.

models.name: Synergy Principle
models.definition: Design combinations where integrated value exceeds sum of parts
models.example: Bundle gait analysis with metabolic testing to increase average revenue per user beyond either service alone.

models.name: Chunking
models.definition: Group related elements into meaningful units to reduce cognitive load
models.example: Organize employee handbook as five macro sections rather than fifty flat chapters, easing navigation and comprehension.

models.name: Functional Composition
models.definition: Chain pure operations where output of one becomes input of next
models.example: Compose ETL pipeline as extract | transform | load where each stage has clean interfaces and defined outputs.

models.name: Interdisciplinary Synthesis
models.definition: Merge insights from distinct fields to generate novel solutions
models.example: Combine biomechanics expertise with UX design principles to create injury prevention app with actionable movement cues.

models.name: Emergence
models.definition: Recognize higher-order behavior arising from component interactions beyond individual properties
models.example: Observe referral flywheel forming organically when individual incentives, network effects, and product value align unexpectedly.

models.name: Gestalt Integration
models.definition: Perceive and leverage whole patterns rather than isolated components
models.example: Design brand identity where logo, color palette, typography, and voice form coherent unified impression.

models.name: Network Effects
models.definition: Exploit increasing value as user base or connections grow
models.example: Structure community features so member directory, skill-sharing, and local groups become more valuable with each new participant.

models.name: Layered Abstraction
models.definition: Separate concerns into hierarchical levels with clear interfaces between them
models.example: Architect system with presentation, business logic, and data layers isolated for independent modification and testing.

models.name: Interface Contracts
models.definition: Define explicit agreements about data structures and behavior between components
models.example: Specify JSON schemas for partner API to ensure data exchange remains stable across independent evolution.

models.name: Pipeline Orchestration
models.definition: Coordinate sequential stages with explicit handoffs and error handling
models.example: Design nightly batch process as ingest → validate → clean → transform → train → report with retry logic.

models.name: Pattern Composition (Tiling)
models.definition: Combine repeating elements to construct complex structures efficiently
models.example: Build design system from atomic components (buttons, inputs) that compose into molecules (forms) and organisms (checkout flows).

models.name: Modular Interoperability
models.definition: Ensure independent components work together through standardized connections
models.example: Design analytics modules to accept common event schema, enabling mix-and-match reporting without custom integration.

models.name: Cross-Domain Analogy
models.definition: Transfer solution patterns from one domain to solve problems in another
models.example: Apply manufacturing's just-in-time inventory principles to content creation workflow, producing articles closer to publication needs.

models.name: Platformization
models.definition: Extract common capabilities into reusable infrastructure serving multiple use cases
models.example: Convert custom authentication into platform service supporting web app, mobile app, and partner integrations.

models.name: Combinatorial Design
models.definition: Systematically explore option combinations to find optimal configurations
models.example: Test A/B/C pricing × 3 billing periods × 2 feature sets to identify best-converting offer structure.

models.name: System Integration Testing
models.definition: Verify assembled components work correctly together, not just in isolation
models.example: Test complete user journey from signup through payment through first value delivery in production-like environment.

models.name: Orchestration vs Choreography
models.definition: Choose between centralized coordination or distributed peer-to-peer interaction
models.example: Implement order fulfillment as choreography where services react to events rather than central orchestrator managing all steps.

models.name: Knowledge Graphing
models.definition: Represent information as interconnected entities and relationships rather than isolated documents
models.example: Build internal wiki as graph where concepts, people, projects, and decisions link, enabling discovery through relationships.

models.name: Multi-Modal Integration
models.definition: Synthesize information from different sensory or data modalities
models.example: Combine quantitative metrics, qualitative feedback, behavioral logs, and market signals into unified health assessment.

models.name: Holistic Integration
models.definition: Unify disparate elements into coherent, seamless whole where boundaries dissolve
models.example: Merge onboarding, product education, customer support, and community into continuous integrated member experience.

models.name: Root Cause Analysis (5 Whys)
models.definition: Iteratively ask why problems occur until fundamental cause emerges
models.example: Throughput declined because rework increased because validation was skipped because deadline pressure exceeded process discipline.

models.name: Factorization
models.definition: Separate multiplicative components to understand relative contribution of each factor
models.example: Express revenue as demand × capacity × conversion to isolate whether growth requires more leads, slots, or optimization.

models.name: Modularization
models.definition: Partition system into self-contained units with minimal interdependencies
models.example: Restructure monolithic program into independent tracks (strength, mobility, nutrition) each manageable separately.

models.name: Layered Breakdown
models.definition: Decompose from system to subsystem to component progressively
models.example: Map service delivery as platform → core services → API endpoints → database queries for targeted troubleshooting.

models.name: Dimensional Reduction
models.definition: Focus on most informative variables while discarding noise or redundancy
models.example: Condense dashboard from 47 metrics to 8 key indicators that capture essential health of business.

models.name: Taxonomy/Classification
models.definition: Organize entities into hierarchical categories based on shared properties
models.example: Classify support tickets into technical, billing, education, feature request for routing and pattern analysis.

models.name: Pareto Decomposition (80/20)
models.definition: Identify vital few drivers producing most impact versus trivial many
models.example: Discover 3 SKUs generating 75% of revenue, enabling focused inventory and marketing optimization.

models.name: Work Breakdown Structure
models.definition: Hierarchically divide project into deliverable-oriented components with clear ownership
models.example: Decompose product launch into marketing, engineering, operations, legal branches, each with sub-tasks and owners.

models.name: Signal Separation
models.definition: Distinguish meaningful patterns from random variation or confounding factors
models.example: Isolate seasonal trends from promotion effects from organic growth in sales data using time series decomposition.

models.name: Abstraction Laddering
models.definition: Move up and down conceptual hierarchy to find appropriate solution level
models.example: Reframe increase trial signups as reduce friction (up) or simplify form fields (down) depending on insight needs.

models.name: Scope Delimitation
models.definition: Define precise boundaries of what is included versus excluded from consideration
models.example: Limit analysis to domestic market, active users, past six months, excluding pilots and enterprise contracts.

models.name: Constraint Isolation
models.definition: Identify specific limiting factor preventing performance improvement
models.example: Determine throughput bounded by database connections, not server CPU, focusing optimization efforts appropriately.

models.name: Failure Mode Analysis (FMEA)
models.definition: Enumerate potential failure points with severity, likelihood, and detectability ratings
models.example: List payment processor outage, inventory stock-out, delivery delay with criticality scores to prioritize safeguards.

models.name: Variable Control & Isolation
models.definition: Hold factors constant to measure single variable's causal impact
models.example: Test new algorithm by fixing traffic source, user cohort, and time period while varying only recommendation engine.

models.name: Decision Tree Expansion
models.definition: Map choices and their consequences as branching paths
models.example: Structure pricing strategy as acquire customer → discount tier decision → retention outcome tree to evaluate paths.

models.name: Hypothesis Disaggregation
models.definition: Break compound claim into testable sub-hypotheses
models.example: Split new design will increase engagement into separate tests of comprehension, navigation, and feature adoption.

models.name: Orthogonalization
models.definition: Ensure factors vary independently without correlation or interdependence
models.example: Design A/B test with independent variations in headline, image, and call-to-action for clean attribution.

models.name: Scenario Decomposition
models.definition: Partition future possibilities into discrete, mutually exclusive scenarios
models.example: Plan for high-growth, steady-state, and contraction scenarios separately with distinct strategic responses.

models.name: Critical Path Unwinding
models.definition: Trace longest sequence of dependent tasks determining minimum project duration
models.example: Identify legal review → security audit → compliance certification chain as immovable timeline constraint.

models.name: Partition-and-Conquer
models.definition: Divide problem into independent subproblems solvable separately then combined
models.example: Split database migration into schema conversion, data transfer, and application cutover as parallel workstreams.

models.name: Recursive Improvement (Kaizen)
models.definition: Continuously refine process through small, frequent enhancements
models.example: Hold weekly retrospective to identify one process friction point and implement fix, compounding improvements.

models.name: Feedback Loops
models.definition: Create mechanisms where system outputs influence future inputs
models.example: Implement churn alerts that trigger retention outreach, which reduces future churn, strengthening the feedback cycle.

models.name: Meta-Learning (Learn-to-Learn)
models.definition: Improve the process of learning itself, not just domain knowledge
models.example: After each training program, evaluate what made learning effective and refine training methodology accordingly.

models.name: Nested Narratives
models.definition: Structure information as stories within stories for depth and memorability
models.example: Present case study (story) containing tactical choices (nested stories) each illustrating broader principles (framing story).

models.name: Fractal Reasoning
models.definition: Recognize self-similar patterns repeating across different scales
models.example: Observe daily stand-up, weekly review, quarterly planning exhibiting same rhythm of sync, reflect, adjust pattern.

models.name: Recursive Framing
models.definition: Apply mental models to the process of selecting mental models
models.example: Use decision tree (DE15) to choose between decision tree and scenario planning for strategic decisions.

models.name: Self-Referential Logic
models.definition: Create systems that monitor, measure, or modify themselves
models.example: Build telemetry infrastructure that tracks its own reliability, automatically adjusting monitoring thresholds based on learned patterns.

models.name: Bootstrapping
models.definition: Build capability using currently available resources, then use that to build more
models.example: Start with manual process, automate most painful step, use time saved to automate next step.

models.name: Iterative Prototyping
models.definition: Cycle rapidly through build-test-learn loops with increasing fidelity
models.example: Ship two-week gait assessment pilot, gather feedback, refine protocol, expand to four weeks, repeat.

models.name: Compounding Cycles
models.definition: Design systems where gains reinforce future gains exponentially
models.example: Grow content library → improve SEO → drive more traffic → generate more content ideas → expand library.

models.name: Calibration Loops
models.definition: Repeatedly check predictions against outcomes to improve forecasting accuracy
models.example: Compare estimated task durations to actual completion times monthly, adjusting future estimates based on error patterns.

models.name: Bayesian Updating in Practice
models.definition: Continuously revise beliefs as new evidence arrives, weighting by reliability
models.example: Update conversion rate estimates after each campaign, incorporating both prior experience and latest results.

models.name: Gradient Descent Heuristic
models.definition: Iteratively adjust toward improvement, even without perfect knowledge of optimal direction
models.example: Experiment with pricing in small increments, moving toward revenue-maximizing point through successive tests.

models.name: Spiral Learning
models.definition: Revisit concepts at increasing depth, building on previous understanding
models.example: Teach strategy fundamentals in onboarding, revisit with case studies quarterly, culminate in strategic planning facilitation.

models.name: Convergence-Divergence Cycling
models.definition: Alternate between expanding possibilities and narrowing to decisions
models.example: Brainstorm features broadly (diverge), evaluate feasibility (converge), explore top three deeply (diverge), select one (converge).

models.name: Retrospective→Prospective Loop
models.definition: Use systematic reflection on past to inform future planning
models.example: Conduct project post-mortem, extract learnings, incorporate into next project's kickoff planning.

models.name: Versioning & Diff
models.definition: Track changes over time and compare versions to understand evolution
models.example: Version control documents, policies, and models to identify what changed, why, and with what effect.

models.name: Anti-Catastrophic Forgetting
models.definition: Preserve critical knowledge while adapting to new information
models.example: When retraining recommendation model, maintain performance on established use cases while improving on new patterns.

models.name: Auto-Refactor
models.definition: Systematically improve system structure without changing external behavior
models.example: Schedule regular code refactoring sprints to reduce technical debt, improving maintainability for future development.

models.name: Recursive Governance (Guardrails that Learn)
models.definition: Establish rules that adapt based on their own effectiveness
models.example: Implement content moderation policies that adjust thresholds based on false positive and false negative rates.

models.name: Leverage Points
models.definition: Identify intervention points where small changes produce disproportionate effects
models.example: Shift default option from opt-in to opt-out for newsletter, dramatically increasing engagement with minimal effort.

models.name: System Boundaries
models.definition: Define what is inside versus outside system scope for analysis or design
models.example: Clarify whether data governance includes partner systems or stops at API boundary to determine responsibility.

models.name: Stocks & Flows
models.definition: Distinguish accumulations from rates of change affecting them
models.example: Track active member stock with new join flow and churn flow to understand growth dynamics and intervention points.

models.name: Requisite Variety
models.definition: Match control system's complexity to system being controlled
models.example: Develop triage playbooks categorized by incident type, severity, and context rather than one-size-fits-all response.

models.name: Systems Archetypes
models.definition: Recognize recurring dynamic patterns across different domains
models.example: Identify shifting the burden pattern where quick fixes undermine fundamental solutions, perpetuating problems.

models.name: Feedback Structure Mapping
models.definition: Diagram causal loops showing how variables influence each other
models.example: Map how quality improves retention, which increases resources, which enables quality investment, creating reinforcing loop.

models.name: Path Dependence
models.definition: Acknowledge how early decisions constrain future options through accumulated consequences
models.example: Recognize initial technology choices now lock in vendor ecosystem, affecting all subsequent architecture decisions.

models.name: Homeostasis/Dynamic Equilibrium
models.definition: Understand self-regulating mechanisms maintaining stable states despite disturbances
models.example: Design recovery rules that automatically scale infrastructure during traffic spikes, then scale back down.

models.name: Phase Transitions & Tipping Points
models.definition: Identify thresholds where gradual changes produce sudden qualitative shifts
models.example: Recognize 40% referral rate as tipping point triggering organic growth that sustains without paid acquisition.

models.name: Causal Loop Diagrams
models.definition: Visualize circular cause-effect relationships with reinforcing and balancing dynamics
models.example: Diagram wait time → satisfaction → reviews → demand → wait time loop before adding capacity.

models.name: Governance Patterns
models.definition: Design decision rights, accountability structures, and coordination mechanisms
models.example: Establish RACI matrix defining who is Responsible, Accountable, Consulted, Informed for cross-functional initiatives.

models.name: Protocol/Interface Standards
models.definition: Specify rules for interaction enabling coordination without central control
models.example: Define REST API standards allowing independent team services to communicate without coordination overhead.

models.name: Incentive Architecture
models.definition: Design reward and penalty structures aligning individual actions with system goals
models.example: Structure sales compensation to reward customer lifetime value, not just deal size, reducing churn from poor fit.

models.name: Risk & Resilience Engineering
models.definition: Build systems that fail gracefully and recover automatically
models.example: Implement circuit breakers that isolate failing services, preventing cascading failures across dependent systems.

models.name: Multi-Scale Alignment
models.definition: Ensure strategy, operations, and execution cohere across organizational levels
models.example: Verify individual OKRs roll up to team goals, which support division strategy, which serves company mission.

models.name: Ecosystem Strategy
models.definition: Position organization within network of partners, competitors, and stakeholders
models.example: Develop platform that attracts third-party integrations, creating ecosystem value beyond internal capabilities.

models.name: Policy Feedbacks
models.definition: Anticipate how rules shape behavior, which creates conditions affecting future rules
models.example: Predict expense policy tightening will drive shadow spending workarounds, undermining both compliance and efficiency.

models.name: Measurement & Telemetry
models.definition: Instrument systems to capture state, changes, and anomalies for informed response
models.example: Deploy monitoring that tracks error rates, latency, throughput, and resource utilization across service mesh.

models.name: Meta-Model Selection
models.definition: Choose appropriate framework or tool for specific problem characteristics
models.example: Select between financial modeling, simulation, and scenario planning based on uncertainty type and decision stakes.

models.name: Systems-of-Systems Coordination
models.definition: Manage interactions between independent systems with emergent behaviors
models.example: Coordinate across supply chain, inventory, logistics, and fulfillment systems each with own optimization but requiring global coherence.
